abstract.p: Charles Siebert's April 8 article on efforts by animal shelters to match people with dogs in need of adoption prompts letters from Marian Schwager and Roman Hedges, Betty Burkett, Debra Griggs, Karen Dawn, Jane Shakman, Deborah Smith-Bernstein and Alan R Witty

block.p: Charles Siebert's article (April 8) provided good insight into the experiences of people like us looking to adopt a shelter dog. Charles Siebert's article (April 8) provided good insight into the experiences of people like us looking to adopt a shelter dog. When we started on the quest, we were taken aback by the psychological grilling associated with the adoption process. The shelter even insisted on conducting home visits to ''check us out.'' Had we not read the article, we would have continued in our assumption that the rescue folks were well intentioned but way over the top in their desire to get the adoption process to stick.

Our local animal shelter does not handle the number of animals that Town Lake does, but its intake is still way too high for our small area. The people who manage the shelter do their best to find homes for their charges. What a horrific job, to walk the runs making decisions that mean life and death for animals.

Diane Mollaghan, an animal-behavior researcher, says shelter dogs who are about to be killed ''vomit or soil themselves the minute they enter the euthanasia room.'' How heartbreaking that they know they are about to die, and how humbling. For if they do know, then they must be very smart.

I send thanks for your strong coverage of shelter-animal adoption, though I did have some discomfort with Siebert's tale of putting himself on the waiting list for the cutest dog. I have a friend who found a cat she adores by walking into a shelter and asking, ''Who has been here the longest?''
Thank you for Charles Siebert's poignant article. I always look forward to his work and he hasn't disappointed me so far. He is a great friend to our nonhuman friends.

Siebert does mention that many dogs that make their way into shelters are purebreds; however, he does not reveal that most of these are the product of puppy mills that churn out an endless supply of merchandise for pet stores. These farms are not overly concerned that negative traits, both behavioral and physical, may have been bred into these animals.

Why so many abandonments? Given the nature of our culture, is it any surprise? The parent left in the nursing home, the homeless man who valiantly served his country. This is a message that we hear all the time: money and convenience over compassion and loyalty.
